newsitem.title: USA: Campbell board best, ADM worst - Business Week.
newsitem.headline: Campbell board best, ADM worst - Business Week.

text.p: Campbell Soup Co.'s board of directors was ranked the nation's best by Business Week, while scandal-ridden Archer Daniels Midland was at the bottom of the list, the magazine said in its latest issue released Thursday.

"Campbell's board copped the top spot because it is helping to redefine the role a modern board of directors should play in a well-managed corporation," Business Week said. "Its published governance guidelines are among the most stringent and far-reaching in Corporate America."
The board of General Electric Co. ranked second, followed by International Business Machines Corp., Compaq Computer Corp., Colgate-Palmolive Co. and Chrysler Corp.
At three of these top companies, the boards outsted their chief executives for poor performance, replacing them with CEOs who have made a radical difference, Business Week said.
Among the worst, "the board at scandal-ridden Archer Daniels Midland has been widely assailed by outsiders for its cronyism and passivity under Chairman Dwayne Andreas," it said.
Last month, ADM said it agreed to plead guilty to two federal counts of price fixing in the sale of agricultural products and to pay record fines totalling $100 million.

Business Week said companies with ineffective boards include Champion International Corp., H.J. Heinz, Rollins Environmental Services Inc., NationsBank Corp. and AT&T Corp., Business Week said. "The companies tended to fail the tests of independence or accountability."
The rankings are based on a survey of 295 of the nation's top pension funds, money managers and experts on corporate governance.
The overall scores were a composite of the survey results plus a board analysis performed by Business Week.
